It was an illustrative fact, that they would only be brought in contact with some three or four buildings of that period, and only one of these of a State character That one was the Chapel Royal of Stirling, built by James VI., 1566, for the baptism of his eldest son Henry, and even this was built before the union of the crowns, and its present condition, which they would see was an interesting instance of the results of the subsequent changes, where James VII., (James II. of England,) when Duke of York, stayed 1681. The other buildings, viz., the Argyll lodging at Stirling, now a hospital; Newark House at Port-Glasgow, a quadrangular building of the sixteenth century, bearing this inscription over the door " The Blessing of God be thereon," now included in a timber yard; and Torwoodhead Castle, now a roofless ruin, were private dwellings, and as such were even in their best days the evidences not of public prosperity, but of individual opulence.
